content.description:
This is a good warm-up. Do a sit start on the arete left of the

Dihedral

.

Sit start below the huge white flake...follow the jugs up.  Top out on smaller but still solid holds. It is a very fun warmup/beginner problem.  For a fun link up, start here and climb up, across to the left and finish going down the dihedral problem.
content.location: This is on the right side of the face of the Trailside Egg.

content.description: Start with a S.D.S. on poor crimps (the top of one looks like it has broken off since the F.A.!!), Navigate the sharp/crimp madness straight up towards the looming bulge.  Just before the bulge, from the poor crimps, get a gross left undercling!!  Move up your feet and push out the bulge to better holds and the finish!!  A very sharp/technical problem.
content.location:
This is located to the right of "

The Haus Toss

."

content.description: Start just right of the dihedral. Use a left hand undercling and a right hand sidepull to move into tough holds at the top.
content.location: This is on the Trailside Boulder.

content.description:
This is the shorter variation of

Second Edition

without the SDS. Start with a high, good, right hand crimp and a decent, slightly sloping, left hand edge. Pull on, and get your left hand into a small undercling. Bring your feet up, and cut for the solid ledge feature at the lip.
content.location: It is in the middle of the boulder on the obvious chalked up line with the prominent bucket at the lip.

content.description:
This line is a sit start that stays a bit right of

Second Edition

and left of the

V0 crack

.  It starts on opposing side pulls about 5 feet apart from each other - the left hand can either start on a 3 finger slopey edge or the sharp crimp on  "

Second Edition

", and the right hand start hold is a really low sloped sidepull/undercling in a white streak a foot or so left of the

V0 crack

.  Get your feet on the good holds about six inches off the ground and pull on.  Move to a 1/4 to 1/2 pad crimp (up and in) with you right hand (crux).  Then climb up and over the bulge, staying left of the crack.  I did not climb into the same finish as

Second Edition

, but I think that would probably also be doable.

This is a very fun and delicate dihedral problem with some finger power and interesting footwork required. Start with fingers matched in a slot at about crotch height. A tiny, difficult-to-match lip provides starting feet. Work your way up the dihedral until you can reach the midway jug at the lip. You can either use the ledge to the left and top out that way, or eliminate the ledge altogether and top out up right with a series of sloping rails and a proper mantle move.

The up-and-right topout adds a + to the grade and makes for a much more interesting experience.
Climb the crack up to the lip. Follow the lip around to the right, and finish around the right more and up.  Watch for the rocks below.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter.
content.location: This is on the Trailside Egg Boulder at the big white crack/flake.

content.description:
Start at the

V0

crack, go up the crack, and go right to crimps at the lip. Find 2-3 holds up and right on the face. Mantel the lip (don’t bash your shin in the lip).
content.protection: 1-2 pads and a spotter helps if you’re scared of mantels.
content.location: This is on the Southeast side of Trailside Egg Boulder at a big white crack/flake.
